item.title: ğŸ“ Appointed as Associate Editor of IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
item.description:
Appointed as Associate Editor of IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement ğŸ“˜

I am honored to share that I have been appointed as an Associate Editor (AE) of IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement (IEEE TIM), following an invitation based on my recognized contributions to the journal as both an author and reviewer.

IEEE TIM is widely regarded as the leading journal in Instrumentation and Measurement, ranked No. 1 in General I&M by Impact Factor and positioned in Q1 of both the Instruments & Instrumentation and Electrical & Electronic Engineering categories of the Journal Citation Reports (JCR). Serving on its editorial board is both a privilege and a responsibility that I value greatly.

Editorial Role and Responsibilities âœï¸

As an Associate Editor, I will contribute to the peer-review and editorial decision-making process, supporting the journalâ€™s mission to publish high-quality, rigorous, and impactful research across the full spectrum of instrumentation and measurement science.

In this role, I will contribute to the review of research on measurement and analysis in bioengineering and biomedical instrumentation, including wearable sensing, physiological signal acquisition, real-time and longitudinal measurements, and measurement-based decision support, with a focus on AI- and machine learningâ€“driven methods addressing real-world instrumentation challenges such as signal quality, reliability, robustness, and interpretability in healthcare settings.

item.title: ğŸš€ Mentoring at the 2025 Harvard HSIL Hackathon â€“ London Hub
item.description:
Mentoring at the 2025 Harvard HSIL Hackathon â€“ London Hub ğŸŒ

I was honored to serve as a local mentor and judge at the 2025 Harvard HSIL Hackathon â€“ London Hub, held on April 11â€“12. This dynamic event, led by Prof. Josip Car and organized by Dr. Lei Lu, brought together 19 global hubs across 18 countries to address critical healthcare system challenges under the theme â€œBuilding High-Value Health Systems: Leveraging Artificial Intelligenceâ€.

As part of the London Hub, I had the privilege to guide and evaluate outstanding student teams from top institutions including Oxford, Cambridge, Imperial, UCL, KCL, LSHTM, and more. The energy, creativity, and collaborative spirit displayed during the hackathon were truly inspiring.

Tackling Key Health Challenges ğŸ’¡

Over two intensive days, teams designed AI-powered solutions focused on:

  • â¤ï¸ Cardiovascular Disease
  • ğŸ§  Mental Health
  • ğŸ¤° Maternal Health
  • ğŸ“š Health Literacy
  • ğŸ‘©â€âš•ï¸ Healthcare Workforce Shortages

It was incredibly rewarding to see participants engage in meaningful problem-solving, supported by mentorship and rapid iteration.

Congratulations to the Winning Teams ğŸ†

I extend my warmest congratulations to the two winning teams for their visionary approaches to global health issues:

  • Adriana Taurinskaite, Prakhar Vats, Vikas Vyas
  • Avni Jambholkar, Bharti Devi, Henry Holms, Hyunhee Lee, Joana Teixeira

Their projects reflected a deep understanding of both technical innovation and real-world impact.

Acknowledging the Community ğŸ’¬

Special thanks to the incredible organizing team and fellow mentors, including:

  • Hanbin Yu, Pauline Lee, Mengzhe Xu, Tapabrata Rohan Chakraborty, Dregan Alexandru, and Dr. Lei Lu
  • Our inspirational speakers: Hayley Ormandy and Joseph Casey
  • And the support from Kingâ€™s College Londonâ€™s School of Life Course & Population Sciences and Kingâ€™s Population Health Institute

ğŸ’– Grateful appreciation also goes to Prof. Rifat Atun and the Harvard team for providing this global platform to foster impactful innovation and collaboration.
